sentences: While Wendy was weaving warm wool, Victor verified the velvet voucher and waved at the warehouse window.
Weary villagers waited in the valley while Vera vowed to video the vivid waterfall.
Three thin thieves thoughtfully threaded thirty silk sashes through thick thistle thorns without a single scratch.
Theo thinks the thermostat’s theme is subtle, but six students say the setting still seems too stiff.
These zealous zoologists gather those zesty datasets, then these analysts theorize why those zebras zigzag.
Those zero-sum theories puzzle these thinkers, though these others prize those zany, buzzing hypotheses.
We breathe beneath the eaves while the sea breeze weaves through the leaves; Keith believes the breeze eases if we breathe evenly.
Please breathe before you seize the sleeves, because the brief breeze freezes the quay; Bree breathed slowly as the breeze teased the trees.
Fiona fried fresh fish while Hank heated hearty hash, and the family felt full before the hikers hurried home.
Farmers fixed fences as hot winds hissed; later, hikers found the high foothills felt friendly.
Pete steered the sleek ship to meet the meek sheep at the steep seaside, while Pip slipped and missed his ticket.
The fleet needs clean sheets and neat meals, but the little ship’s kitchen still sticks and drips.
Luke stood with a full rucksack by the school, but Lou, the class clown, yelled “Move!” like a fool and tripped over the stool.
Brooke put books in the full blue cupboard, yet Bruce, too cool, chose to loop the route to the room.
The black cat napped on Jack’s backpack, while Ben set the red bed near the desk and kept his pen ready.
Pam had a stack of maps, but Deb kept a set of menus; the cat sat on the mat as the guests headed to bed.
Pat grabbed a cap and dashed for the cab, while Gus clutched a cup and trudged up the bus steps in a rush.
Jack packed snacks and caps in a canvas bag; Judd dug up mugs and cups, then snugged them under the truck.
Tom got a cotton cot for the cold loft, but Dawn caught a warm thought and bought broad boards for the floor.
Don locked the shop at one o’clock; Dawn, who’d caught the forecast, bought more salt for the storm.
As the sun begins to rise, Rose rinses rice and arranges bowls, while Lewis organizes supplies and closes the doors.
Denise weighs bags of rice as the prices rise, and Carlos analyzes sales before he files the reports.
The town council wrote the rules down, but one young runner was done before the countdown even sounded.
She counted every noun in the passage and jotted them down, while none of the others had done even one.
We drove around the brown town at sundown, then ran one lap and were done by sunup.
A hound on the hunt gave a grunt on the ground, another hound on the hunt heard the grunt and the sound, so he joined in the hunt with a grunt on the ground.
He found a one-pound coin on the path, walked to the pond, flipped the pound in the air, and heard it plop into the pond.
Workers pound wooden posts into the ground around the pond to anchor the rail, while the ranger surveys the pond for frogs.
Don switched the lights on in the town hall, and the crowd sat down around the brown stage.
John put on his gown in the old town and wrote the rules down before the camera went on.
The clown drove around the town at sundown while Don waited on the corner with his badge on.
We passed around the brown gown for costumes, and John tried it on when his name was called.
The choir sat down as the town bell rang, and Don turned the microphones on for the next round.
The teacher told them to note each key noun and write it down, while John kept the timer on.
The town council pinned a brown crown cutout down, and Don checked whether the sign was still on.
Tour guides led us around the old town, then John pressed on with the talk while we settled down.
The judge sat down in the town court, and Don switched on the clock to begin the session.
We cooled down by the town gate while John left the porch light on so everyone could see.
Don wrote the rule down, but Don said it was already done.
The town planned a fair; John put the signs on; by noon the setup was done.
She counted each noun, skipped each non-example, and marked none as done.
He tossed a pound to the pond fund and joked that one more pun would get it done.
They found the trail, ignored the fond detours, and raised a fund when the work was done.
The hound waited by John while the hungry kids wrote the chores down and got them done.
We cooled down in the old John-street ton-weight room after the lifts were done.
She set the sound meter on, greeted her son, and said the tests were almost done.
The town clock went on at dawn; by dusk a ton of repairs were done.
He tried the green gown, checked if it was on, then declared the tailoring done.
The judge wrote down the charge, the clerk put it on file, and the payment was done by noon.
We passed around the list, pinned it on the board, and crossed off each task as done.
Jane saw heavy rain, while Jan said he already ran and planned a new plan for the late train.
We will plan the route before the plane, then write it down so the rain won’t ruin what we planned.
The baker sifted bran as the intern studied a brain scan and Jane explained the plan again.
The coach said Stan should avoid a sprain, so stain guards were cleaned after the match and the plan remained the same in the rain.
Chan drew a chain on the map; the team ran the trail while light rain cooled the plain.
We can test the cane and the crane on-site, but we can’t switch the plan if the rain delays the plane.
He placed a camping cot by the wall, then took a call in the hall and forgot the cooking pot.
Paul checked the pot on the hob, then made the call to install a second cot for the guest.
The boss saw a chipped ball in the hall, swapped the broken box, and logged the loss.
We will stock the shop before the lunch stall, then spot each shortfall and restock what we saw on the wall of the hall.
She hung a winter shawl by the clock, wiped the shop top, and wrote one more call note on the log.
He set the collar tag correctly so the caller could reach us; later, a loose bottle cap fell near the ball rack while I stirred the pot.
The man asked the men to pass the map, and the men handed the man a pen.
Jan planned the route while Jen penned reminders and sent them at ten.
We set the frying pan beside the red pen, then the chef said the pan can stay but the pen must go.
If you can, ask Ken to check the van; if Ken cannot, you can send an email.
We will land the deal today, but we will not lend funds until Monday.
Do not dump sand in the chute; send the bags to the site instead.
The team met in Canton while Kenton called in from the road and then sent the agenda.
The base camp opened at dawn, and Kemp confirmed the permits by ten.
Brandon mapped the canyon while Brendan amended the tender and sent notes to the panel.
We moved the fallen branch off the path and then lifted the park bench to the lawn for the event.
